Articles.Content: As many people know, 1.0 heat overhaul has caused huge FPS drops, and it drops very quickly with more than 150 parts. However, in many crafts these are antennas or batteries that don't need to be simulated. What I suggest is that we give the same internal/external temperature of the root part to the physics-less part, while keeping both parts max temp. This allows batteries to still burn up during high velocity reentries, but saves on heat and conduction calculations. It could also be applied to parts like the cubic octagonal strut, by making it's temp the average of the two parts around it- certain parts like struts and fuel lines shouldn't even be simulated at all. What do you guys think about adding this?

Except heat often goes THROUGH some of these parts to reach others. Surface-mounted parts in particular are susceptible to being heated FIRST from re-entry effects, and are legitimately hotter than their parent because they can't transfer the energy fast enough.
But does that really matter enough to seriously damage performance and FPS?

On the one hand, a battery sticking to the side of the vessel rightfully receives a lot heat. However, batteries are a bad example. Radial chutes, ladders, landing gear... all of these have to be visible on the outside for us to see them and to provide us with something to click and toggle. But by rights, they should be flush with the surface.
